Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Oxide-Derived Metal Nanoparticles for CO2 Electroreduction Catalysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Catalysis Program of the National Science Foundation, Professor Kanan and his students will develop and study heterogeneous electrocatalysts for the conversion of CO2 into fuels and synthetic building blocks. The research will focus on a new class of catalysts called "oxide-derived metal nanoparticles". These catalysts are prepared by electrochemically reducing bulk metal oxide precursors to form metallic nanoparticles, which exhibit dramatically improved energetic efficiency for CO2 reduction and resistance to deactivation. The surface structures will be probed by a combination of electrochemical techniques, spectroscopic methods and high-resolution electron microscopy, which are complemented by electrokinetic measurements to illuminate mechanistic features of CO2 reduction. Concurrent with their experimental activities, researchers in this project will perform high-level comparative analyses of electrochemical, photoelectrochemical and chemical approaches to CO2 recycling.

The longstanding reliance on fossil fuels as the principal energy source for society has boosted the atmospheric CO2 concentration to an unprecedented level, which necessitates recycling CO2 into fuels using renewable energy inputs. The proposed research addresses one of the greatest scientific hurdles to this vision: the development of energy-efficient and selective CO2 reduction catalysts. These catalysts could be incorporated into an electrolytic device that produces carbon-based fuels when powered by a photovoltaic or wind turbine.

POR.DRECONTENT:
CO2 electrolysis is the conversion of CO2 and H2O into O2 and fuel using an electrical power source. This process—effectively a combustion reaction in reverse—is of great interest for the development of renewable alternatives to fossil fuels. The efficiency of CO2 electrolysis depends greatly on the efficiency of the electroreduction catalyst at the cathodic (negative) electrode that mediates the transfer of electrons and protons to CO2 to produce the fuel. This project sponsored by the NSF Chemical Catalysis program originated in the PI’s lab with the development of “oxide-derived” metals, a novel class of CO2 electroreduction catalysts. Oxide-derived metals are prepared by electrochemically or chemically converting a metal oxide precursor into a metallic material. We had discovered that certain oxide-derived metals such as oxide-derived Au and oxide-derived Cu have enhanced catalytic properties for CO2  electroreduction compared to their parent bulk materials or to nanoparticle films. The technical goals of this project were to elucidate the structural origin of these catalytic properties and use these insights to prepare further improved catalysts.

Our research activities resulted in three main findings: i) Through transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and X-ray diffraction studies, we found that oxide-derived metals are nanocrystalline, meaning that they are composed of individual crystallites with nanoscale dimensions linked together in a continuous material by a network of grain boundaries (Nature, 2014, 508, 504). This finding motivated the hypothesis that the grain boundaries were important to the catalytic activity of oxide-derived metals. ii) In testing this hypothesis, we found that there is indeed a quantitative correlation between the density of grain boundaries in Au nanoparticles and their activity for CO2 electroreduction to CO, an important feedstock molecule for fuel synthesis (J. Am. Chem. Soc., 2015, 137, 4606). This work suggests a new design principle for metallic electrocatalysts: the incorporation of a high density of grain boundaries to support catalytically active surfaces that are unstable in the absence of grain boundaries. iii) Through extensive investigations of Pd-catalyzed CO2 reduction, we showed that there are two catalytic regimes with this material (J. Am. Chem. Soc., 2015, 137, 4701). At minimal potentials (i.e. potentials close to the thermodynamic minimum), Pd efficiently catalyzes the reduction of CO2 into formate (HCO2–), an important commodity chemical. This activity slowly degrades, however, because of the formation of a small amount of CO that poisons the electrode surface. At more energetic potentials, Pd exclusively catalyzes the electroreduction of CO2 to CO. This work shows that Pd could be a highly efficient catalyst for electrochemical formate synthesis if the electrode poisoning problem is solved.

Our research activities have been complemented by extensive efforts to disseminate the results both to the scientific community and the general public. The PI has discussed electrochemical CO2 conversion in the context of renewable energy technology with numerous media outlets, including KQED Science in San Francisco, Reuters, MIT Tech Review, The Des Moines Register, and “A Moment of Science” on public radio. These discussions have likely stimulated significant interest in chemical research to address environmental issues in the general public. In addition, the PI has begun introducing discussions of CO2 conversion research into the introductory undergraduate chemistry curriculum to engage future scientists early on in their undergraduate education. 

 


Last Modified: 08/30/2016
Modified by: Matthew Kanan
